Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 46025-001  
Regional—Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (PATA) 
November 2012 
 
 
 
Joint Control of Transboundary Animal Diseases in 
the People’s Republic of China and Mongolia 
(Cofinanced by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  RCI  –  regional cooperation and integration 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TAD  –  transboundary animal disease 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—policy and advisory technical assistance (R-PATA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Agriculture and natural resources (livestock) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Regional cooperation and integration (other regional public 
goods); capacity development (client relations, network, and 
partnership development) 
Location (impact)  –  Rural (high); regional (high) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  R. Wihtol, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  Y. Qian, Public Management, Financial Sector, and Regional Cooperation 
Division, EARD 
   
Team leader  Y. Zhang, Senior Regional Cooperation Specialist, EARD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Since 2006, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has provided technical assistance (TA) 
to develop and implement regional cooperation between the People’s Republic of China (PRC) 
and Mongolia in the priority areas of transport, trade facilitation (customs cooperation and 
logistics development), and electric power trade, achieving initial but important progress.1 The 
two  countries  recently  agreed  to  explore  new  areas  of  cooperation,  and  the  sanitary  and 
phytosanitary area is regarded as a new priority for cooperation. They have further agreed that 
the joint prevention and control of transboundary animal diseases (TADs) will be an early focus. 
This regional policy and advisory TA responds to requests from the two governments for ADB to 
continue to support PRC–Mongolia cooperation. The fact-finding mission visited the PRC and 
Mongolia on 5–9 March 2012 to discuss with government officials and other stakeholders the 
impact, outcome, outputs, cost, financing arrangements, and implementation arrangements for 
the TA. Consultations were later conducted with the two governments during a Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) workshop on sanitary and phytosanitary measures 
held in Bangkok on 25–26 July 2012. Broad agreement and support was obtained for the TA. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Strategy 2020 highlights regional cooperation and integration (RCI) as one of five core 
operational areas.3 In line with the strategy, ADB will increase support for RCI to include it in at 
least 30% of its activities. The PRC and Mongolia attach great importance to RCI. Both are 
active in RCI initiatives, including the ADB-led CAREC Program and the United Nations-led 
Greater Tumen Initiative and Northeast Asia Economic Cooperation Forum. The PRC country 
partnership strategy, 2011–2015 identified regional cooperation as one of three pillars of ADB 
assistance, using ADB's RCI programs to enhance regional infrastructure connectivity, facilitate 
cross-border trade and investment, and promote regional public goods.4 The Mongolia country 
partnership strategy, 2012–2016 treats regional cooperation as a crosscutting theme.5 Regional 
cooperation is critically important for Mongolia as a landlocked country, offering it opportunities 
to strengthen infrastructure and trade links with its neighbors, diversify its economy, and realize 
its growth potential.  
 
3.  The PRC and Mongolia face a common threat posed by TADs, in particular foot and 
mouth disease, porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (also known as blue-ear pig 
disease), and highly pathogenic avian influenza. The two countries share a border stretching 
4,700 kilometers. Animal husbandry plays an important role in the economic development of 
border provinces of both countries and is vulnerable to TADs. Recurrent outbreaks in domestic 
and wild animals have caused tremendous harm to animal health and safety. They also pose 
serious threats  to  human  health  and  may  cause  huge  economic  losses. The International 
Federation  for  Animal  Health  reported  that  an  outbreak  of  foot  and  mouth  disease  from 
November 2010 to April 2011 in the PRC, Japan, the Republic of Korea, and Mongolia required

the culling of 3.5 million animals and an emergency vaccination program, inflicting losses of 
$2.8 billion.6  
 
4.  Animal diseases incur costs in terms of (i) lost production, which disproportionally affects 
herders and farmers in rural and border areas who are often  economically vulnerable; (ii) 
resources needed to monitor and control outbreaks; and (iii) harm to human health and welfare. 
When animal diseases cross borders, as often happens, costs are even higher, and prevention 
and control become more complex and difficult. In a rapidly globalized economy, TADs can 
trigger  trade  restrictions  on  animal  products,  especially  meat,  dairy,  and  leather  goods. 
Mongolia is vulnerable to such trade restrictions because animal product exports are important 
revenue sources for the country.  
 
5.  The persistence and spread of TADs stem from various factors, including the migration 
of wild animals, illegal border trade in animal products, and cross-border grazing. The lack of a 
cross-border and regional mechanism for policy dialogue, information sharing, and joint action 
worsens the situation. Weak capacity for TAD control—particularly in terms of surveillance, data 
collection and analysis, laboratory testing, and community monitoring and emergency response 
in rural and border areas—is another constraint on TAD prevention and control. In the PRC and 
Mongolia, as in many other developing countries, veterinary services urgently need bolstering. 
To prevent the spread of TADs across the borders, countries need to adopt effective measures 
nationally and through regional cooperation. 
 
6.  On 2 November 2011, a memorandum of understanding on animal health cooperation 
was signed by the Bureau of Veterinary Service of the PRC’s Ministry of Agriculture and by 
Mongolia’s Department of Veterinary and Animal Breeding. The memorandum commits the two 
countries  to  taking  joint  efforts  to  prevent  and  control  TADs.  Both  countries  have  also 
emphasized the need to cooperate with other CAREC countries and are seeking ADB support 
for  launching  a  regional  platform  for  cooperation  on  TAD  control  and  other  sanitary  and 
phytosanitary issues. The TA supports cooperation between the PRC and Mongolia and more 
broadly in the CAREC in this new and important area. It will help the two countries formulate 
policy recommendations toward establishing a regional mechanism for the joint prevention and 
control  of  TADs  and  conduct  priority  capacity-building  programs.  Where  necessary  and 
appropriate, the TA will encourage and support the participation of other parties in Central Asia, 
particularly in information exchange and knowledge sharing.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact will be strengthened regional cooperation to prevent and control TADs in the 
PRC, Mongolia, and more broadly in the CAREC region. The outcome will be a well-functioning 
institutional mechanism for cooperation to jointly prevent and control TADs in the PRC and 
Mongolia. 
 
8.  The TA will contribute to the objectives of ADB’s Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Strategy, particularly on promoting regional public goods (pillar 4) and facilitating cross-border 
trade (pillar 2).7 The enhanced control of TADs will lower barriers to trade in animal products 
                                                
6  Oxford Analytica. 2012. The Cost of Animal Disease—A Report Produced for the International Federation for 
Animal Health. Oxford. 
7  ADB. 2006. Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy. Manila.

3 
and help strengthen commitments from governments in the region to prevent communicable 
diseases. The lessons and experience from the TA will benefit sanitary and phytosanitary 
cooperation now being launched as a priority activity in the CAREC trade facilitation program. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
9.  The impact and outcome will be achieved through the following outputs: 
(i)  a study report on establishing a mechanism for PRC–Mongolia cooperation to 
jointly  control  major  TADs,  which  will  recommend  policies  and  steps  toward 
establishing such a mechanism and analyze the feasibility of and options for 
involving other countries and parties in Central Asia; 
(ii)  a manual on community-level TAD prevention and control to guide animal health 
workers in the border communities of the two countries;  
(iii)  enhanced capacity for TAD prevention and control in PRC and Mongolian border 
provinces  achieved  by  preparing  a  5-year  capacity-development  plan  and 
organizing training workshops; and  
(iv)  policy briefs and/or best practice notes for senior decision makers of the PRC 
and Mongolia. 
 
10.  The TA will   
(i)  conduct  studies  and  organize  international  expert  seminars  to  discuss  and 
recommend policies and steps toward establishing a PRC–Mongolia cooperation 
mechanism to jointly prevent and control TADs; 
(ii)  organize consultations to help the PRC and Mongolia establish a joint working 
group on preventing and controlling TADs, and organize working group meetings;  
(iii)  prepare a 5-year capacity-building plan and organize training for veterinarians 
and  other  animal  health  workers  in  border  provinces  on  priority  subjects, 
particularly  strengthening  TAD  surveillance  and  improving  animal  health 
information systems; 
(iv)  prepare and distribute to communities a manual on community TAD prevention 
and control, focusing on early detection, data collection and preliminary analysis, 
designing and implementing community emergency responses, and information 
dissemination; and  
(v)  organize workshops on knowledge sharing with other CAREC countries.  
 
11.  Much of the TA budget will be spent on training, workshops, and seminars. Training 
veterinarians and animal health workers in border areas on TAD surveillance and animal health 
information systems is a high priority of both governments, as weak capacity in these areas is a 
main constraint on TAD control. Workshops and seminars will be organized to (i) help the two 
governments agree on the best institutional mechanism for TAD control; (ii) enable the team of 
international and national consultants to conduct sufficient consultation to ensure that the policy 
recommendations and operational manual they prepare fully reflect countries’ needs; and (iii) 
share experience and knowledge with other CAREC countries.  
 
12.  The TA will help assess training needs for TAD control, formulate a 5-year capacity-
building plan, and explore partnerships for capacity building with other international and bilateral 
agencies, including the Food and Agriculture Organization and the World Health Organization. 
As funding available under the TA is limited relative to needs, the TA will finance only the 
highest-priority capacity building.

4   
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which (i) $250,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund,8 and (ii) $250,000 will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The 
governments of the PRC and Mongolia will jointly provide counterpart support in the form of 
counterpart  staff,  office  space,  support  for  training,  seminars,  and  conferences,  and  other 
administrative and logistics services. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months from 1 January 2013 to 31 December 2014. 
ADB will be the executing agency. The implementing agency in the PRC will be the Ministry of 
Agriculture, and, in Mongolia, the Department of Veterinary and Animal Breeding, supported by 
National Center for Zoonotic Diseases under the Ministry of Health. Due attention will be paid to 
coordinating and sharing information with other actors in preventing and controlling TADs, such 
as health ministries, inspection and quarantine agencies, and customs administrations. The 
Ministry of Finance in the PRC and the Ministry of Industry and Agriculture in Mongolia will 
guide  and  coordinate  TA  implementation.  Civil  society  and  community  organizations  with 
interest and expertise in TAD prevention and control in the two countries, particularly in border 
provinces,  will  be  engaged.  The  Financial  Sector,  Public  Management,  and  Regional 
Cooperation Division of ADB’s East Asia Department will administer and implement the TA in 
collaboration with the PRC and Mongolia resident missions. Lessons from other ADB projects 
related  to  sanitary  and  phytosanitary  cooperation,  particularly  under  the  Greater  Mekong 
Subregion Economic Cooperation Program, will be applied. The monitoring and reporting of 
implementation progress and outcome—covering cost, time, risk, quality, human resources, 
procurement,  and  communications—will  be  carried  out  by  the  ADB TA  project  officer  and 
support team through periodic reviews in accordance with the design and monitoring framework.  
 
15.  Advisory and technical services will require 5 person-months of international consultancy 
and 12 person-months of national. Technical resource persons will be required. The consultants 
and  resource  persons  will  be  specialists  in  epizootiology,  regional  cooperation  and  policy 
coordination for TAD control, and institution and capacity building. Because TA activities will be 
varied,  ADB  will  engage  consultants  and  resource  persons  as  individuals  based  on  their 
qualifications and experience and in accordance with ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Appendix 3 provides the outline terms of reference for 
consultants and resource persons. Office equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  transferred  to  the 
implementing agencies upon TA completion. TA proceeds will be disbursed in line with ADB’s 
Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The 
advance payment facility can be used for equipment, seminars, workshops, and conferences. 
 
16.  The TA outputs, particularly study findings and recommendations, will be disseminated 
in the PRC, Mongolia, and other CAREC countries through workshops, seminars, conferences, 
publications, and the media in line with ADB procedures. Where appropriate, representatives of 
the secretariats of other regional cooperation bodies will be invited to dissemination events.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
the Joint Control of Transboundary Animal Diseases in the People’s Republic of China and 
Mongolia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Up  to  5  person-months  of  international  consultant  inputs  and  12  person-months  of 
national will be needed to realize the objectives of the regional policy and advisory technical 
assistance (TA). These terms of reference are preliminary and will be expanded in consultation 
with  the  governments  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  and  Mongolia  during 
implementation. The consultants will report to Asian Development Bank (ADB) task manager(s) 
for the TA, who will be responsible for coordinating TA activities. The international and national 
consultants will be required to submit (i) an inception report and work schedule within 1 month of 
mobilization; (ii) a draft final report 1 month before the contract ends for review and comments 
from ADB and the governments; and (iii) a final report in hard and soft copies, incorporating all 
comments.  
 
A.  International Consultant  
2.  Epizootiology specialist and team leader (5 person-months). The specialist will be 
engaged to help develop an institutional mechanism for PRC–Mongolia cooperation to prevent 
and  control  transboundary  animal  diseases  (TADs).  The  specialist  should  be  a  regional 
cooperation expert in TAD control with at least a master's degree, and preferably a PhD, in 
epizootiology and/or epidemiology. The specialist should have at least 10 years of professional 
experience in the field and extensive work experience in East and Central Asia. Responsibilities 
will include 
(i)  reviewing and analyzing existing institutional arrangements on jointly preventing 
and  controlling  major  TADs  in  East  and  Central  Asia,  with  an  emphasis  on 
relevance and application in the PRC and Mongolia;  
(ii)  reviewing institutional arrangements for monitoring and controlling major TADs 
and the lessons and experiences of other regions;  
(iii)  reviewing existing data and information, and collecting new data and information 
if necessary, on patterns of animal flow across the PRC–Mongolia border, and 
assessing risk;  
(iv)  organizing workshops and seminars to introduce and share experiences from 
other countries and regions on monitoring and controlling TADs, analyzing TAD 
risks  in  PRC  and  Mongolia  border  areas,  and  discussing  and  developing 
coordinated and integrated TAD prevention and control measures;  
(v)  organizing seminars that include international experts to discuss and recommend 
policies and steps for establishing a PRC–Mongolia cooperation mechanism for 
jointly preventing and controlling TADs;  
(vi)  conducting research and preparing a report on establishing a PRC–Mongolia 
cooperation  mechanism  for  jointly  preventing  and  controlling  TADs,  and 
recommending options and approaches to expand this mechanism to involve 
other countries participating in the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation; 
(vii)  organizing  and/or  conducting  training  for  veterinary  personnel  in  PRC  and 
Mongolian  border  provinces  with  respect  to  TAD  monitoring  and  laboratory 
testing; and  
(viii)  supporting national animal disease monitoring experts’ application of international 
best  practices  in their research  and  providing technical guidance to  national 
consultants  toward  preparing  a  manual  on  community  TAD  prevention  and 
control.

10  Appendix 3 
 
B.  National Consultants  
3.  Animal  disease  monitoring  and  public  health  experts  (four  experts,  12 person-
months total). Two experts each from the PRC and Mongolia will be recruited to prepare a 
manual on community TAD prevention and control and assist the international consultant by 
researching  and compiling government  policies  and  procedures,  collecting  data,  translating 
documents, and ensuring that the work produced by the international consultant meets regional 
and national needs. Candidates should have at least a master’s degree in a relevant field, a 
good command of the English language, and a minimum of 10 years of professional experience 
in animal disease monitoring. Priority will be given to candidates with experience in formulating 
policies  on  disease  prevention  and  control  and  in  implementing  TA  projects  financed  by 
international organizations. Responsibilities will include  
(i)  reviewing existing data and information, and collecting new data and information 
if necessary, on patterns of animal flow across the PRC–Mongolia border, and 
assessing disease risk;  
(ii)  preparing  a  bilingual  manual  in  Chinese  and  Mongolian  on  community  TAD 
prevention and control, which will serve as guidelines for community programs 
and efforts to monitor, prevent, and control major TADs, including foot and mouth 
disease, porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome, and highly pathogenic 
avian influenza;  
(iii)  helping organize and attending workshops and seminars on monitoring TADs and 
assessing  their  risks,  and  providing  technical  inputs  to  workshops,  including 
presentations on patterns of cross-border animal flow and animal disease risk 
analysis;  
(iv)  assisting the international consultant and providing technical inputs into the study 
on establishing a PRC–Mongolia cooperation mechanism for jointly preventing 
and controlling TADs;  
(v)  preparing training materials; and  
(vi)  helping  organize  training  programs  for  veterinary  personnel  in  PRC  and 
Mongolian  border  provinces  with  respect  to  TAD  monitoring  and  laboratory 
testing.  
 
C.  Resource Persons (international and national) 
4.  Resource persons may be engaged to help prepare, attend, or present to conferences, 
seminars, and training events organized under the TA.
